anchor.surface_text: section 9  1   iv  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922. The relevant portion of that section reads thus The tax shall be payable by an assessee under the head Income from Property in respect of the bonafide annual value of property companysisting

The relevant portion of that section reads thus The tax shall be payable by an assessee under the head Income from Property in respect of the bonafide annual value of property companysisting of any buildings or lands appurtenant thereto of which he is the owner, other than such portions of such property as he may occupy for the purposes of any business, profession or vocation, carried on by him the profits of which are assessable to tax, subject to the following allowances, namely -  i   ii   iii  where the property is subject to a mortgage or other capital charge, the amount of any interest on such mortgage or charge where the property is subject to an annual charge number being a capital charge, the amount of such charge, where the property is subject to a ground rent the amount of such ground rent and, where the property has ,been acquired, companystructed, repaired, renewed or reconstructed with borrowed capital, the amount of any interest payable on such capital

concepts.interpretation: Deduction limited to interest on original capital charge (simple interest at 6 3/4%); compound interest is interest on interest, not on capital charge; real capital charge is originally due amount; allowing compound would enable tax evasion by own default

arguments.court_reasoning: Compound interest is not interest on the original capital charge but interest on unpaid interest; only simple interest on original capital charge is deductible.

arguments.court_reasoning: Income-tax Officer correctly allowed only Rs. 18,000/- simple interest; compound interest not deductible under section 9(1)(iv).

arguments.claim: The interest (compound) is an interest paid on the capital charge.

anchor.surface_text: Hence we are unable to accept the contention of the assessee that the interest is an interest paid on the capital charge.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the assessee has agreed to pay interest. Hence we are unable to accept the companynection of the assessee that the interest is an interest paid on th

arguments.court_reasoning: Unable to accept; it is additional interest due to failure to pay, not on capital charge.

arguments.claim: The law permits the client to deduct any interest paid on the capital borrowed or charged, including compound interest.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Chagla, the learned counsel for the assessee, contended that the law permits his client to deduct any interest paid by him on the capital borrowed or charged and any interest included compound interest also.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: charge. Mr. Chagla, the learned companynsel for the assessee, companytended that the law permits his client to deduct any interest paid by him on the

arguments.court_reasoning: Fallacious argument; compound interest payable not on capital charge but on interest; not covered by section 9(1)(iv).

arguments.claim: The law permits deduction of the amount of any interest on such mortgage or capital charge.

anchor.surface_text: It must be bore in mind that what, the law permits is the deduction of the amount of any interest. on such mortgage or charge.

arguments.claim: Compound interest is liable upon failure to pay interest per contract; it is interest on interest, and unpaid interest becomes part of principal but not original capital charge.

anchor.surface_text: The interest payable by the assessee on the capital charge was at the rate of 6 3/4 per annum. But if he fails to pay that in accordance with the terms of the contract, he was liable to pay compound interest. In other words, if he fails to pay interest in accordance with the contract, he was liable to pay interest on interest.

arguments.claim: The assessee is entitled to deduct interest payable on the capital charge, not additional interest considered part of loan due to failure to pay.

anchor.surface_text: What the assessee is entitled to deduct is the interest payable by him on the capital charge and not the additional interest which because of his failure to pay the interest on the due date had been considered as a part of the loan. In fact, the real capital charge is that which was originally due.

arguments.claim: Accepting deduction of compound interest would open door for tax evasion by debtors not paying interest regularly and claiming deduction.

anchor.surface_text: If we accept Mr. Chaglas contention as correct, then the door will be open for evasion of tax. All that the debtor need do is not to pay interest regularly but utilise that amount for other purpose and make the Revenue pay compound interest payable by him and thus derive advantage out of his own omission.

arguments.claim: The interpretation placed by the High Court is the correct interpretation.

anchor.surface_text: Such an interpretation is impermissible. We are clearly of the opinion that the interpretation placed by the High Court is the correct interpretation.

holdings.text: What the assessee is entitled to deduct is the interest payable by him on the capital charge and not the additional interest which because of his failure to pay the interest on the due date had been considered as a part of the loan. In fact, the real capital charge is that which was originally due.

anchor.surface_text: What the assessee is entitled to deduct is the interest payable by him on the capital charge and not the additional interest which because of his failure to pay the interest on the due date had been considered as a part of the loan. In fact, the real capital charge is that which was originally due.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Additional interest from default becomes part of loan but not original capital charge; deductible interest limited to that on original capital charge.

holdings.text: Hence we are unable to accept the contention of the assessee that the interest is an interest paid on the capital charge.

anchor.surface_text: Hence we are unable to accept the contention of the assessee that the interest is an interest paid on the capital charge.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Compound interest is merely interest on interest agreed upon due to default, not on capital charge.

holdings.text: This, to our minds, appears to be a fallacious argument. The compound interest is payable not on the capital charge but on that part of the interest on which he has agreed to pay interest. That is not the capital taken note of by section 9(1)(iv).

anchor.surface_text: This, to our minds, appears to be a fallacious argument. The compound interest is payable not on the capital charge but on that part of the interest on which he has agreed to pay interest. That is not the capital taken note of by section 9(1)(iv).

holdings.reasoning_summary: Compound interest falls outside scope of 'interest on such mortgage or capital charge' as it is interest on interest.

holdings.text: If we accept Mr. Chaglas contention as correct, then the door will be open for evasion of tax. All that the debtor need do is not to pay interest regularly but utilise that amount for other purpose and make the Revenue pay compound interest payable by him and thus derive advantage out of his own omission. Such an interpretation is impermissible.

anchor.surface_text: If we accept Mr. Chaglas contention as correct, then the door will be open for evasion of tax. All that the debtor need do is not to pay interest regularly but utilise that amount for other purpose and make the Revenue pay compound interest payable by him and thus derive advantage out of his own omission.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Allowing compound interest deduction rewards default and enables tax evasion by deliberate non-payment of interest.

holdings.text: We are clearly of the opinion that the interpretation placed by the High Court is the correct interpretation.

anchor.surface_text: We are clearly of the opinion that the interpretation placed by the High Court is the correct interpretation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court's view that assessee not entitled to compound interest deduction under section 9(1)(iv) aligns with textual meaning and policy.
